fields.description:
Currently if you are not an active crucible user, a permission denied message is shown when you click on the reviews tab. 

Elsewhere in the UI we hide things you do not have access to, so we should probably do the same here.
fields.summary: Hide the Reviews tab from users without "Active Crucible User" box selected.

fields.description:
Whilst crucible emits ReviewUpdatedEvents for things as trivial as a review name change, no event is emitted when the content of a review changes.

*Proposed solution A*: add a new event class, ReviewContentUpdatedEvent, and emit those when review contents are changed.
Why not just emit more ReviewUpdatedEvents ? Because it is nice to be able to distinguish between content changes and details changes.  
*Proposed solution B*: just emit more ReviewUpdatedEvents.
fields.summary: Crucible doesn't emit any events when content is added or removed from a review.

fields.description:
We would like to achieve something like in the attached screenshot (works for me on these Cru instances where I have admin rights as profile pictures now are accessible now via REST only by admins)
Profile picture is anyway accessible if one has the access to given review, so IMO we are not exposing any security breach here.

Having said that, I don't think that the best place for exposing profile pictures to all authorized users would be via rest-service/users-v1/{{username}} (a lot of calls from clients would be needed and it may be tricky to decide if if someone is authorized to see other's profile, or not).

I'd rather go for including profileUrl in {{detailedReviewData}} (if one has access to given detailedReviewData, he or she has access to profile images too), e.g.
{noformat}
<creator>
<displayName>John Smith</displayName>
<userName>john.smith@mail.com</userName>
<avatarUrl>http://foo.bar/abc.png</avatarUrl>
</creator>
{noformat}
The same goes for other elements describing users: {{reviewer}}s, {{author}}, {{moderator}} or perhaps just all elements from newly created {{reviewParticipants}}.

As we may need to get the access to both small and big pictures (16x16 and maybe 64x64 pixels) we may consider actually serving two URLs for each user listed in the review:
{noformat}
<avatarUrl>http://foo.bar/abc.png</avatarUrl>
<smallAvatarUrl>http://foo.bar/abc.png</smallAvatarUrl>
{noformat}

Alternatively we may consider extending the elements returned by {{/rest-service/users-v1}} with these avatar URLs.
The former will not require to do any client side caching of meta-data. The latter will require it, but we can live with it I bet.

I'd appreciate if you could include it in one of the incoming Cru 2.2 sprints (before March).
fields.summary: Expose via REST API URLs to avatar (profile) pictures for non-admin users

fields.description:
Moving our JSON responses from {{application/ecmascript}} to {{application/json}} will enable the JSON explorer tab in Firebug when viewing AJAX requests/responses.

[rfc4627|http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4627.txt] recommends {{application/json}}.
fields.summary: Move JSON responses to application/json content-type

fields.description:
I need a way to view a list of reviews in which
- i'm a participant,
- are closed, and
- have unread comments or files.

The use case the following sequence of events:
1. I complete a review (which leaves all files/comments read, one way or another).
2. The author comments on the review.
3. The author closes the review.

This particular review will no longer show up in 'My Open Reviews' which is where I normally keep tabs on which reviews have activity I haven't seen yet.

This lack of this filter option is the only thing that keeps me using email notification of comments.
fields.summary: Custom review filter needs an 'unread' option

fields.description: We're using host mode to authenticate users, but while Crucible treats the users as case sensitive and windows doesn't we end up with problems.  You can login as "USERNAME" and setup your profile and get assigned reviews.  Then you log out and log back in as "username" to check your reviews.  You won't have any, because Crucible just created a new user id for you.  You're in the system twice.  People start assigning reviews to the wrong user id, and email notifications aren't sent.  It becomes a big mess very quickly.
fields.summary: The user name in host mode is case sensitive even in windows

where the numbers in brackets are the number of lines added and removed -- but that isn't essential to knowing what happend to the file (added/copied/moved).

fields.description:
We have our Crucible configured to only allow authenticated users to see content. Someone was given a link to their project (e.g., http://fisheye.example.com/project/example) and when they clicked on the link, they get the repositories list with an error message:


The requested resource cannot be found.
No such project

It would be nice if this took them to the login page instead. (Or if I could configure things to take them to the login page instead -- I realize that some people might think that taking them to the login page is a security leak.)
fields.summary: If a non-logged-in user clicks a link to something they must be logged in to see, it would be nice to ask them to log in instead of showing them an error.

fields.description: I have had a concern raised about the date format for the due date field in Crucible. In my locality, we are used to a MM/DD/YYYY date format. When you pick a date from the date picker it inserts it into field in a DD/MM/YYYY format. What may be worse is if a user manually types a due date in MM/DD/YYYY format giving unexpected results. I would like to suggest that the date format should be configurable by an administrator but the default should remain DD/MM/YYYY.
fields.summary: make due date format administratively configurable

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Using Crucible standalone
2. Add a File System Repository Plugin
3. Create a review for this repository
4. Include a file (e.g. test.txt) into the review via the 'Files' section
5. Edit the file (e.g. test.txt) from the file system
6. Refresh the review and click on the 'Edit Revisions' button. There will be 2 revisions displayed ([screenshot|http://content.screencast.com/users/chaiying/folders/Jing/media/fea0b318-ce80-4d41-a809-4ca09f82ea87/2010-01-05_1157.png])
7. By selecting the newer revision, it does not take any effect.
fields.summary: Not able to select revision using File System Repository Plugin

fields.description:
I'm using FishEyes EyeQL to query FE/CRU about review coverage. In order to do this I need to be able to tell when the EyeQL data is finished indexing. Currently, it is possible to tell whether the FE data is finished, but not the Crucible data.

As a result, I'm getting perfect data for FE, but often completely wrong (or no) data for crucible.
fields.summary: Repository Indexer doesn't indicate the status of crucible index data.

fields.description: In an agile permission scheme, any reviewer can add or edit content in a review. Crucible assumes that any changes are always made by the author, and so if a reviewer makes a change the author is not notified.

fields.description:
If you happen to add a commit message e.g "CR-111" (not a code review id), crucible will read this as a review id which doesn't exist and shows "Review Not Found". It still showing as a link even you've changed the project key to other key.

Steps to reproduce:
# Add a file with commit message e.g CR-111
# Create a review with "default" project key "CR" then add the file to the review
# You should see the CR-111 shows as a link
# Change the project key from CR to other key e.g MP
# The existing reviews key will change to MP-xxx, but the commit message CR-111 still showing as a link which doesn't exist.
fields.summary: Link still shows on non exists review id

fields.description:
We create all the crucible revisions for a changeset in a single transaction, which holds the uniqueRowLock for the duration of the transaction. This means that review contents cannot be edited until the crucible revisions have been created.

We should batch the creation of crucible revisions into smaller transactions.
fields.summary: FileRevisionManager.createRevisions may hold unique row lock for a long time

fields.description:
Its possible to get the following error when adding a file to a review from the filesystem repo.

{noformat}Caused by: com.cenqua.crucible.model.FileRevisionException: java.io.IOException: Revision 2009-12-23T15:18:32.000+1100 of file myfile.txt is no longer available.
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.scm.SCMSource.copyFile(SCMSource.java:281)
        at com.atlassian.fisheye.scm.SCMSource.getFileContents(SCMSource.java:265)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.revision.managers.DefaultContentManager.getContents(DefaultContentManager.java:583)
        at com.cenqua.fisheye.diff.DiffHelper.getDiffExp(DiffHelper.java:82)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.revision.source.Source.getDiffPrinter(Source.java:207)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.view.FRXDO.getDiffPrinter(FRXDO.java:1139)
{noformat}

Steps to reproduce:

# Create a filesystem repo 
# Add a file myfile.txt to the repo
# Create a review and add myfile.txt from the repo
# Edit myfile.txt
# Edit the review and reload the files tab of the repo
# Select the newest revision but before clicking "Done" *edit the file again* 
# Click Done and an exception will be thrown when the review reloads

!http://img.skitch.com/20091223-gkrem28w1tekuys6mq9ff9nfdd.jpg! 

The side affect of this is that viewing the file in crucible, it will appear to spin indefinitely with a "Loading diff..." message.
fields.summary: com.cenqua.crucible.model.FileRevisionException when adding revisions to a review using a filesystem repo

Steps to reproduce:
# Create a new review

# Click Uploads
# Browse the "File to review" options
# Select a test file and upload it
# Modify the text file content
# Select the modified text file and upload it
fields.summary: Uploaded revisions are considered "Added" instead of Updated/Changed

fields.description:
*Steps*
1. Go to a review with many files, e.g., http://localhost:6060/crucible/cru/CR-FE-2803
2. Select the very last file in the file navigation tree.
3. Toggle the diff mode, i.e., Prefs > Side-by-side Diffs (assuming it was previously in unified mode).

*Expected*
- The file you are viewing immediately reloads to the diff mode you selected.

*Actual*
- There is a very noticable delay before the file you are viewing is reloaded to the new diff mode.
fields.summary: Long delay when toggling diff mode when viewing last file in review

fields.description:
Each time FishEye needs the contents of a revision, it fetches it from the underlying SCM system.

FishEye should use some sort of per-repository, LRU, space-limited cache of the contents of revisions.
We should independently cache the text and binary versions of files (text versions are requested much more frequently)
Consider gz compression of files.
Consider reusing the file-on-disk when returning the StreamIndexedLineReader so as to reduce double-copying.
The cache state should be preserved across FishEye restarts.

The default size of this cache (per repository) should be 500MB. It should be customizable in the admin.
fields.summary: disk-based bounded cache of the contents of revisions in FE

Of course as a work around you can put the JIRA issue key in the review title and search by that.

fields.description:
FE-2273 implemented a check where the list of "all users" in the Crowd application was filtered by the authorized-groups returned by Crowd.

The problem is, the Directories associated with an Application in Crowd can be marked "allow all users", and we don't check for that.

We need a better way to ask Crowd for the list of all users visible by this Application.
fields.summary: Crowd-authentication is still not correctly respecting the list of "authorized users"

fields.description:
1. fisheye.report.tab passes the report.tab.key property to {{<report:toolbar currentTab="${reportKey}" path="${path}" />}} but this doesn't seem to highlight a name on the toolbar
2. crucible.report.tab seems to render the toolbar itself, ignoring report.tab.key
3. These decorators need to be documented, including the fisheye.report.tab repository.path parameter.
fields.summary: Report Tab Decorators don't highlight selected report

fields.description:
The logic which determines which reviews are in the _To Summarize_ state incorrectly assumes that the review must have all completed reviewers and the *moderator* as the current user. If there is no moderator, then this logic needs to use the author of the review.

This is not a simple change, as the Hql query in {{ReviewManager.java}} (ide link: [!http://localhost:51235/icon!|http://localhost:51235/file?file=trunk/src/java/com/cenqua/crucible/model/managers/ReviewManager.java]) is very complex, and our schema makes it difficult to simplify.

The way to solve this is to abandon the Hql queries and do a lucene search on denormalised review documents.
fields.summary: "To Summarize" filter is incorrect when there is no moderator on reviews
Flexibility to change the color syntax highlighting for different codes (java, c-sharp etc) directly in existing Fisheye/Crucible

fields.description: A user should be able to attach existing JIRA issues to a review comment. The workaround today is to mention the issue in the comment but a tighter integration could be a better option.

fields.summary: Quicknav fails to report exception:  TooManyClauses
quick nav is making ajax calls to non "/json/" urls, which means if it errors, it returns a html error, instead of a json error to be displayed in a dialog
